passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 120.00 ZAR | Price: 115.05 ZAR

While we welcome Sasol's guidance for improving volumes in FY26 across all key segments (see Exhibit 1), we await results of execution (especially destoning) leading to a sustained recovery in volumes. Further, we believe macro both in oil and cements remains uncertain, capping any significant rerating potential in the near- term. Post results, we leave our FY26E- 28E earnings broadly unchanged. We increase our PO from ZAR 100/US\(5.41 to ZAR 120/US\)6.86 as we :1) increase target multiples in our SOTP valuation for various segments based on management guidance of improving volumes in FY26 (accounting for \(13\%\) of our PO increase), 2) roll- forward DCF by a year (7% of our PO increase). Next key catalyst: 1Q FY26 production update in October.

Sasol highlighted that the destoning plant construction is complete, with start- up later in this calendar year: this is likely to help Secunda Operations production volumes increase by \(c.6\%\) y/y to 7- 7.2mn tonnes in FY26 as sink content in coal is reduced to 12- \(14\%\) vs sink content of \(>15\%\) over the last 3- 4 years.

Our commodities team projects an average surplus of 890k b/d in 12 months from July 2025 through June 2026. This surplus should result in global oil inventory builds of around 100mn barrels over the same window. The team forecasts average Brent oil price at \(\) 63.50\(/bbl in 2H25 (3Q25E: US\) 66 / bbl, 4Q25E: US\) 61 / bbl).

Sasol trades on a FY26E PE of 3.6x, a \(38\%\) discount to LT 12M Fwd PE average. It also trades on a \(62\% /84\%\) discount to blended refining and chemical peers on FY26E EV/EBITDA and FY26E PE. In our view, sustained operational delivery will be critical for narrowing this discount. Our income rating is now an 8 (same or lower) vs a 7 (same or higher).

SOS is an international integrated energy and chemical company, producing synthetic fuel and chemicals from coal and gas. It is also engaged in the commercial production and marketing of chemicals (polymers, solvents, wax, olefins & surfactants) and liquid fuels. SOL's flagship operations are in South Africa, with a growing presence in the US.

While Sasol trades at a significant discount to global peers on a 12- month forward EV/EBITDA basis, we see catalysts lacking near term to drive a re- rating. Chemical margins remain subdued, while sustained operational recovery is something we need evidence of.
Shares / ADR 1.00 Price to Book Value 0.4x
(US$)PreviousCurrentInv. OpinionC-2-7C-2-8Price Obj.5.416.862026E EPS1.881.872028E EPS2.612.59
Post results, we leave our FY26E- 28E earnings broadly unchanged.

In- line with company guidance, we assume capex will be low in FY26E at ZAR 25.8bn, relatively flat vs FY25 before increasing in FY27E/28E to ZAR 30/31bn. FY26E will not have the phased shutdown at Secunda like FY25 which saw a phased shutdown for 60 days in September 2024. Sasol now has a phased shutdown at Secunda once every year for 4 years and then skips a year (FY26E being skipped). The next phase shutdown at Secunda is in FY27 (September 2027) for 60 days. As a result of this capex is expected to increase again from FY27E onwards.

Exhibit 1: FY26E guidance points towards a stronger operational performance y/y across all segments (FY25 - FY26E) International Chemicals EBITDA expected to increase y/y in the range of US\\$39mn-US\\$139mn based on company guidance

FY26E guidance (key segments)FY25FY26EBofAe FY26EMining saleable production (mn tonnes)28.228-3030Gas production (change y/y)+1%+10%+10%SO production (mn tonnes)6.77.0-7.27.15Chemicals Africa sales volumes (change y/y)-4%0-5% higher3%Liquid fuels sales volumes (change y/y)Mobility +5%, Commercial and wholesale -3%0-3% higher3%Chemicals International adjusted EBITDA (US$mn)411450-550476
Source: Company data, BofA Global Research estimates

Our PO is based on the equal weighted average of i) SOTP based multiple valuation applied to each of the business segments. We apply a multiple to next 12 months EBITDA for Fuels and the Chemicals segments and a reserve based multiple for the Mining and Gas segments, ii) DCF for the entire company. We use a DCF based valuation to consider the company future cash flow profile. We incorporate a SOTP method in our valuation given it reflects the EBITDA generation profile for the company over the next 12 months.
We increase our PO from ZAR 100 to ZAR 120 (up \(20\%\) ) as we:

1) Increase target multiples in our SOTP valuation for various segments based on management guidance of improving operational trajectory in FY26. Higher multiples account for \(13\%\) of our PO increase.
2) Roll forward DCF by one year. This accounts for \(7\%\) of our PO increase.
Our SOTP based valuation methodology yields a NAV/sh of ZAR 135 (vs 108 previously), while DCF yields ZAR 105 (vs ZAR 91 previously).
Our PO of ZAR 120 is based on the equal weighted average of SOTP based multiple valuation method and DCF
Valuation summaryValuation (ZAR /sh)Implied FY 26E EV/EBITDA multipleSOTP based multiple valuation method1353.31DCF1052.94PO (ZAR/sh)1203.13
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
In this method, we arrive at an NAV/sh of ZAR 135. The business units we consider are highlighted below.

For the South African Energy and Chemicals Business unit, we apply a reserve based multiple for the Mining (US\\$1/t) and Gas (US\\$3/boe) segments - unchanged vs previously. For the Fuels segment, we apply an EV/EBITDA multiple of 4x higher than 3.5x multiple we applied previously due to management guidance of operational improvements at Secunda, with volumes expected to be up y/y in FY26E. As shown in, global refining peers trade on a 2025E EV/EBITDA of 4.5x. We believe a discount of c.10% for Sasol is justified vs peer's vs our previous c.15% discount. Similarly, for the Chemicals Africa business we apply an EV/EBITDA multiple of 4x vs 3.5x previously.

For the International Chemicals business unit, we apply a higher 12M Fwd EV/EBITDA multiple of 4.5x for the Americas and Eurasia business vs 4x previously due to a better volume outlook in FY26E post unplanned shutdowns in FY25.

Below we show our calculation using a sum- of- the- parts methodology. Based on our analysis, the South African Energy and Chemicals Business unit comprises c.78% of the EV while the International Chemicals Business constitutes c.22% of the EV.
Exhibit 3: NAV/sh calculation using a sum-of-the-parts methodology We arrive at a NAV/sh of ZAR 135

We incorporate the DCF based valuation method to better capture the cash flow profile of the company over the medium to long- term. We derive our WACC using: (1) cost of equity of 19.1% (Rf= 10.3%, equity risk premium of 4.5% and beta of 2.0); and (2) 6.5% cost of debt post tax.
Exhibit 4:Discounted cash flow (ZAR mn) We arrive at a NAV/sh of ZAR 105

Source: BofA Global Research estimates. Note: Figure highlighted in blue represents our base case scenario

Sasol continues to trade at a significant discount to its own historical long- term 12M Fwd PE and EV/EBITDA averages as well as peer averages. It trades on a FY26E EV/EBITDA of \(3.3x\) , a \(17\%\) discount to LT 12M Fwd EV/EBITDA average. It trades on a FY26E PE of \(3.6x\) , a \(38\%\) discount to LT 12M Fwd PE average. Finally, it trades on a \(62\% /84\%\) discount to blended refining and chemical peers on FY26E EV/EBITDA and FY26E PE.

Sasol's share price has underperformed oil price (ZAR/bbl) since Aug 2023 by \(54\%\) driven by operational concerns vs long- term co- relation of 0.6. With sustained improvement in volumes, we believe the underperformance will reverse, evidence of which we await.

We derive our ZAR 120 (US\(6.86) PO based on the equal- weighted average of i) SOTP based multiple valuation, ii) DCF for the entire company.

In our SOTP- based method, we arrive at an NAV/share of ZAR 135. For the Southern Africa Energy and Chemicals business unit, we apply a reserve based multiple for the Mining (US\(1/t) and Gas (US\)3/boe) segments. For the Fuels and Chemicals Africa segments, we apply an EV/EBITDA of 4x each to the segments 12- month forward EBITDA.
For the International Chemicals business unit, we apply a 12M forward EV/EBITDA multiple of 4.5x for the America and the Eurasia segments.
Our equity value is ZAR 86,263mn, which we divide by no of shares to arrive at ZAR 135/share.

We incorporate a DCF- based valuation to better capture the company's cash flow profile. We use a terminal value growth rate of \(1.0\%\) and a weighted- average cost of capital (WACC) of \(13.5\%\) . We derive our WACC using (1) cost of equity of \(19.1\%\) (RF= \(10.3\%\) , equity risk premium of \(4.5\%\) and beta of 2.0) and (2) \(6.5\%\) cost of debt post tax. We arrive at an NAV/share of ZAR 105 using this approach.

Upside risks: Better- than- expected operational recovery, higher- than- expected oil prices and chemical margins, better- than- expected cost- saving measures, more clarity on an operational roadmap.
Downside risks: Decline in oil price or contraction in downstream margins, stronger than expected ZAR, lower- than- expected cost- saving measure, higher- than- expected carbon taxes and capex.
EEMEA - Energy & Industrials Coverage Cluster

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%

R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster. INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
